dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017

dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017 = <dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017_gen object>

The secondary-star mass random variable of Moe and Stefano (2017)

As an instance of the rv_continuous class, dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017 object inherits from it a collection of generic methods (see below for the full list), and completes them with details specific for this particular distribution.

Methods

rvs(primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1, size=1, random_state=None)

Random variates.

pdf(x, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Probability density function.

logpdf(x, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the probability density function.

cdf(x, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Cumulative distribution function.

logcdf(x, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the cumulative distribution function.

sf(x, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Survival function (also defined as 1 - cdf, but sf is sometimes more accurate).

logsf(x, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Log of the survival function.

ppf(q, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Percent point function (inverse of cdf — percentiles).

isf(q, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Inverse survival function (inverse of sf).

moment(order, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Non-central moment of the specified order.

stats(primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1, moments=’mv’)

Mean(‘m’), variance(‘v’), skew(‘s’), and/or kurtosis(‘k’).

entropy(primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

(Differential) entropy of the RV.

fit(data)

Parameter estimates for generic data. See scipy.stats.rv_continuous.fit for detailed documentation of the keyword arguments.

expect(func, args=(primary_mass,), loc=0, scale=1, lb=None, ub=None, conditional=False, **kwds)

Expected value of a function (of one argument) with respect to the distribution.

median(primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Median of the distribution.

mean(primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Mean of the distribution.

var(primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Variance of the distribution.

std(primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Standard deviation of the distribution.

interval(confidence, primary_mass, loc=0, scale=1)

Confidence interval with equal areas around the median.

Notes

The probability density function for moe2017 is:

\[f_{M_{2}|M_{1} = m_{1}}(m_{2}|m_{1}) = \dfrac{1}{m_{1}}f_{Q}(m_{2}/m_{1}).\]

where

\[f_{Q|M_{1} = m_{1}}(q|m_{1}) = \int_{p_{\min}}^{p_{\max}}f_{(Q, P)|M_{1} = m_{1}}(q, p|m_{1})\mathrm{d}\,p\]

and, by the chain rule for probability,

\[f_{(Q, P)|M_{1} = m_{1}}(q, p|m_{1}) = f_{Q|(P, M_{1}) = (p, m_{1})}(q|p, m_{1})f_{P|M_{1} = m_{1}}(p|m_{1}).\]

for primary-star mass \(m_{1} \in (m_{1}, 60)\), secondary-star mass \(m_{2} \in (0.1m_{1}, 60)\), mass ratio \(q \in [0.1, 1]\), and period \(p \in [10^{0.2}, 10^{8}]\). The functions \(f_{Q|(P, M_{1}) = (p, m_{1})}\) and \(f_{P|M_{1} = m_{1}}\) are the probability density functions for random variables dyad.stats.mass_ratio.moe2017 and dyad.stats.period.moe2017.

moe2017 takes primary_mass as a shape parameter for \(m_{1}\), the primary mass.

The probability density above is defined in the “standardized” form. To shift and/or scale the distribution use the loc and scale parameters. Specifically, secondary_mass.moe2017.pdf(x, primary_mass, loc, scale) is identically equivalent to dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017.pdf(y, primary_mass) / scale with y = (x - loc) / scale. Note that shifting the location of a distribution does not make it a “noncentral” distribution; noncentral generalizations of some distributions are available in separate classes.

References

Moe, Maxwell, and Rosanne Di Stefano. 2017. 'Mind your Ps and Qs: the interrelation between period (P) and mass-ratio (Q) distributions of binary stars.' The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series 230 (2): 15.

Examples

>>> import numpy as np
>>> import dyad
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)

Calculate the first four moments:

>>> primary_mass = 60
>>> mean, var, skew, kurt = dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017.stats(primary_mass, moments='mvsk')

Display the probability density function (pdf):

>>> x = np.linspace(dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017.ppf(0.01, primary_mass),
...                 dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017.ppf(0.99, primary_mass), 100)
>>> ax.plot(x, dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017.pdf(x, primary_mass),
...        'r-', lw=5, alpha=0.6, label='dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017 pdf')

Alternatively, the distribution object can be called (as a function) to fix the shape, location and scale parameters. This returns a “frozen” RV object holding the given parameters fixed.

Freeze the distribution and display the frozen pdf:

>>> rv = dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017(primary_mass)
>>> ax.plot(x, rv.pdf(x), 'k-', lw=2, label='frozen pdf')

Check accuracy of cdf and ppf:

>>> vals = dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017.ppf([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], primary_mass)
>>> np.allclose([0.001, 0.5, 0.999], dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017.cdf(vals, primary_mass))
True

Generate random numbers:

>>> r = dyad.stats.secondary_mass.moe2017.rvs(primary_mass, size=1000)

And compare the histogram:

>>> ax.hist(r, density=True, bins='auto', histtype='stepfilled', alpha=0.2)
>>> ax.set_xlim([x[0], x[-1]])
>>> ax.legend(loc='best', frameon=False)
>>> plt.show()
